Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will further develop an important subfield of mathematics called dynamical systems. This field originated at the end of nineteenth century and at the beginning of twentieth century with the work of great mathematicians such as Henri Poincare and Jacques Hadamard, to mention only two. Their research overlapped with physics, classical mechanics, and differential geometry; this current project is also multidisciplinary. It involves, in addition to dynamical systems, several other subfields of mathematics such as number theory and probability theory. In this project the PI will build on these fields and contribute to their development by laying down rigorous methods as applicable to those fields as to dynamical systems. The project is intended to involve at least eleven scholars from three continents as collaborators. Among them included are four scholars from the United States, one from Canada, five from Europe, and one from Japan. The results of the proposed research will also form a source for further research and provide material for teaching advanced graduated courses. The supported scholars will visit the PI's institution in Denton, Texas to conduct research, deliver seminar lectures, and interact with faculty and graduate students there.


The principal investigator proposes, in seven separate but interrelated subprojects, to advance the theory of Diophantine approximations, transfer (Perron-Frobenius) operators, discrete groups, countable alphabet conformal iterated function systems, holomorphic dynamics, random dynamical systems, and ergodic averages. Diophantine approximations include geometrically extremal measures and badly approximable vectors in finite-dimensional Euclidean spaces. Transfer operators include Apollonian circle packings and dynamical systems with holes. Discrete groups include geometric rigidity for Kleinian groups and Gromov hyperbolic spaces. Conformal iterated function systems include harmonic measure, exact dimensionality, continuity of Hausdorff measure, and non--autonomous conformal iterated function systems. Holomorphic dynamics includes doubling measures and rational semigroups. Random dynamical systems include shrinking targets, dynamical rigidity in random conformal dynamical systems, random conformal iterated function systems with transversality, random rational functions, and random transcendental meromorphic functions. These subprojects will require methods from dynamical systems, ergodic theory, functional analysis, geometric measure theory, number theory, complex analysis, and probability theory. The goal of each subprojects of this proposal is to solve the major dynamical, geometric, and analytical problems related to these fields. It builds upon the methods and results the PI has obtained throughout his entire research career, focusing mainly on about 40 papers written in the past five years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes of this project are formed by  the theorems containded  in the PI's 28 research papers and in 1 book, out of which 18 were published, 6 are accepted for publication and 5 are submitted to peer reviewed professional journals.

The results concern ergodic theory and dynamical systems, particularly thermodynamic formalism, iteration of transcendental meromorphic functions, both deterministic and random, Kleinian groups, deterministic and random conformal iterated function systems, Diophantine approximations, open dynamical systems and escape rates, asymptotic counting in conformal systems, dimension spectra in conformal graph directed Markov systems,

The results were obtained by using and developing methods of ergodic theory, dynamical systems, measure theory including greometric measure theory, functional analysis, complex analysis, Gromov hyperbolic spaces, rectafiablity theory, and numerical methods.

Here is a brief description of some of the obtained results:

The most significant results of  "Dimension Rigidity in Conformal Structures" (accepted in Advances in Math., with T. Das and D. Simmons) concern $\Lambda$, the limit set of a conformal dynamical system, i.e. a Kleinian group acting on either finite or infinite-dimensional Hilbert space, a conformal iterated function system, or a rational function. We give an easy sufficient condition for the dichotomy that $\Lambda$ is either a real-analytic manifold or a fractal. We focus ion the infinite-dimensional case. A key component of our strategy is from the rectifiability techniques of Mayer and Urbanski ('03) (countable IFS case).

"Random Dynamics of Transcendental Functions" (published in Journal d'Analyse Mathematique, with V. Mayer) concerns random dynamics of hyperbolic entire and meromorphic functions of finite order whose derivative satisfy some growth condition. This class contains most of classical families of transcendental functions and beyond. Based on Nevanlinna's  theory we first build a thermodynamic formalism which, in particular, produces unique geometric and fiberwise invariant Gibbs states. Moreover, the spectral gap property (obtained via our construction of new positive invariant cones) for the associated transfer operator along with exponential decay of correlations and a CLT are shown.

In "Non-Escaping Sets in Conformal Dynamical Systems and Singular Perturbations of Perron-Frobenius Operators" (published in  Springer's Lecturre Notes in Mathematics, with M. Pollicott) we prove the existence of appropriate escape rates for all attracting IFSs. Utilizing the method of the first return map, and using large deviation theory, we obtained many applications to dynamical systems such as rational functions of the Riemann sphere, dynamically regular transcendental meromorphic functions, parabolic IFS, and  multimodal maps of the interval.

In "Asymptotic Counting in Conformal Dynamical Systems" (accepted in Memoirs of AMS, with M. Pollicott) we prove the asymptotic formulas for multipliers at inverse images and periodic points for all attracting and parabolic GDMS, all hyperbolic and parabolic rational functions, the Gauss map, the Farey map, Manneville--Pomeau maps, classical Schotky groups without and with tangencies, Apollonian circle packings and the Apollonian triangle.

In "Dimension Spectrum of Conformal Graph Directed Markov Systems" (submitted to Selecta, with V. Chousionis and D. Leykekhman) we prove the fullness of spectrum of many GDMSs. Especially of CCF. This is a computer assisted proof. We use and develop a softwaw to approximate Hausdorff dimension of various limit sets up (high0 to desired accuracy.

In "Badly approximable vectors and fractals defined by conformal dynamical systems" (accepted in Mathematical Research Letters) joint with T. Das, L. Fishman and D. Simmons, we prove that if $J$ is the limit set of an irreducible conformal iterated function system, the badly approximable vectors form a set of full Hausdorff dimension in $J$. The same is true if $J$ is the radial Julia set of an irreducible meromorphic function.

In "Real Analyticity for random dynamics of transcendental functions" (accepted in Ergodic Th. and Synam. Sys., with V. Mayer and A. Zdunik) analyticity results of expected pressure and invariant densities in the context of random dynamics of transcendental functions are established.

In the book "Geometry and Dynamics in Gromov Hyperbolic Metric Spaces, with an Emphasis on Non-Proper Settings" (published in the AMS Mathematical Surveys and Monographs Series, with T. Das and D. Simmons) we present the theory of groups  acting isometrically on Gromov hyperbolic metric spaces. We avoid any assumption of properness. Our theorems extend virtually all major theorems known in the proper case. We discuss diferences at length and provide  examples.

In "Extremality and Dynamically Defined Measures, Part I" (accepted in Selecta), with T. Das, L. Fishmann, and D. Simmons), we present a new method of proving the Diophantine extremality of various dynamically defined measures, vastly enlarging the class of measures known to be extremal. This generalizes and improves the celebrated theorem of Kleinbock and Margulis ('98) resolving Sprindzuk's conjecture, and its extension by Kleinbock, Lindenstrauss, and Weiss ('04).

The project made the PI  possible to develop  an ergodic theory and dynamical systems graduate course as well as to work with doctoral students.
